headline.main: Cheney Plays the Terror Card (2 Letters)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am outraged by Vice President Dick Cheney's completely unfounded claim that Ned Lamont's victory in the Connecticut Democratic Senate primary somehow weakens national security, that it might encourage ''al Qaeda types'' (''Democrats Back Lamont in Race in Show of Unity,'' front page, Aug. 10).
docs.abstract: Two letters respond to Aug 10 article about Democrats' support for Ned Lamont, who defeated incumbent Sen Joseph Lieberman in Connecticut primary; James P Ware says it is Pres Bush and Vice Pres Dick Cheney who have weakened national security, not Ned Lamont's victory; Lee Bergman scores fearmongering by Cheney and calls upon Democrats to quickly counter it and expose it
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     I am outraged by Vice President Dick Cheney's completely unfounded claim that Ned Lamont's victory in the Connecticut Democratic Senate primary somehow weakens national security, that it might encourage ''al Qaeda types''...

docs.lead_paragraph: TERROR PLOT IS FOILED -- British authorities said they had thwarted an advanced terrorist plot to blow up airplanes flying from Britain to the United States using liquid explosives that would have escaped airport security. [Page A1.] NEW SCRUTINY OF BAGGAGE -- Long security lines, missed flights, delayed departures, harried workers and annoyed, sweaty people of every stripe were common in airports across the country as tightened security rules rattled the nation's air system. [A9.] DELAYS TO CONTINUE -- Air travelers will encounter tighter security, including more baggage restrictions, and should arrive earlier than usual at airports, the Department of Homeland Security said. [A9.] AIRLINES IN DOUBT -- The foiled terrorist plot in London that targeted American carriers throws into doubt whether the long-struggling industry will be able to continue its nascent recovery. [C1.] MARKETS SHOW RESILIENCE -- Wall Street withstood the news of a terror plot aimed at commercial airlines. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 48.19 points to close at 11,124.37. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 5.86, to 1,271.81, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 11.46, to 2,071.74. [C6.] EDITORS RESIGN -- The managing editor of CJRDaily.org, an online adjunct of the Columbia Journalism Review, and his deputy both quit after the dean of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism told them he was cutting the site's budget nearly in half. The dean, Nicholas Lemann, above, said the savings would be used in efforts to increase subscriptions to the print magazine. [C3.] TRADE DEFICIT DIPS -- The Commerce Department reported that the deficit in the nation's trade of goods and services reached $64.8 billion in June, modestly below the $65 billion deficit recorded for May. [C1.] DOUBTS OVER SOFT LANDING -- Despite the Federal Reserve's hope for a soft landing for the economy, many economists warn that the Fed is either too rosy about the looming slowdown or naïve about the difficulty of reaching its goal for inflation. [C1.] HEDGE FUND MANAGER WINS BIG -- David Einhorn, a hedge fund manager, does not play much poker, but after entering the World Series of Poker in Las Vegas, the game's most prominent tournament, on a whim, he came in 18th place this week, winning more than $650,000. [C1.] PROPPING UP A SMALL TOWN -- Long a poor cousin in affluent Switzerland, the gritty military town of Andermatt, population 1,400, is bracing for a makeover financed by a wealthy Egyptian that boosters say will propel it into the glittering ranks of the famed resorts of St. Moritz, Zermatt and Davos. [A4.] OUT WITH THE CASHMERE -- Saks Fifth Avenue, which saw disappointing sales as a result of a fall fashion campaign last year focusing on cashmere, is taking a broader approach this year, directing its merchants to pick the 20 biggest fall trends. The lesson, it seems, has been learned: the broader the appeal the better. Advertising. [C3.] JOB DRAIN DISPUTED -- A new study found no evidence that immigrants have taken a large number of jobs from Americans. [A12.] LABOR ADDS PRESSURE -- The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees announced plans to spend $60 million more a year to campaign for universal health coverage, to unionize 70,000 workers annually and to register 280,000 union members to vote. [A12.] GLAXO SETTLES LAWSUITS -- GlaxoSmithKline said it had agreed to pay $70 million in a national settlement of civil lawsuits that accused the company of inflating costs of several medicines, including its blockbuster Zofran nausea drug. [C4.] SOFTWARE COMPANY IN TALKS -- Bain Capital, the private equity firm, was near a deal to acquire Applied Systems, a software company that focuses on the insurance industry, for about $675 million, according to people involved in the transaction. [C6.] ONLINE PRACTICAL TRAVELER -- For frequent travelers, every inch counts when choosing your seat. But packed planes mean tough competition. A report on how to get a window seat rather than an aisle or vice versa is at nytimes.com/travel. EMPLOYEE INFORMATION -- License Monitor Inc. of Congers, N.Y., is one of a growing number of firms that provides companies with up-to-date information on the driver's license status of their employees. A report is at nytimes.com/jobs. A PUSH IN TEXAS -- In an effort to make its state a magnet for research, the University of Texas is planning a $2.5 billion program to expand research and teaching in the sciences. A report is at nytimes.com/science.

docs.lead_paragraph: A former jockey who was paralyzed after falling during a race two years ago has agreed to settle a $10 million lawsuit against the Jockeys’ Guild and two former officials who allowed his health insurance to lapse. Neither the Detroit lawyer Paul Koczkur, who represented the jockey, Gary Birzer, nor the California-based guild disclosed the financial terms of the settlement, which was protected by a confidentiality agreement. Koczkur praised the longtime sports agent Dwight Manley, the new national manager of the Guild, for facilitating the negotiations.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ned Lamont, a Connecticut millionaire whose candidacy for the United States Senate soared from nowhere on a fierce antiwar message, won a narrow victory in the Democratic primary last night over the incumbent, Joseph I. Lieberman. Senator Lieberman, a national party leader and the Democratic nominee for vice president in 2000, conceded defeat in a phone call to Mr. Lamont shortly before 11 p.m. But then, in a combative speech to supporters in Hartford that was carried live on television news, the senator declared that he was not dropping out of the race, but would instead run for re-election as an independent this fall.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ned Lamont won a narrow but decisive victory tonight over the storied incumbent, Joseph I. Lieberman, in the race for the Democratic nomination.
